document.docTitle: Phonotimpus marialuisae Chamé-Vázquez & Ibarra-Núñez 2019, sp. nov.
document.masterDocTitle: A new species of Phonotimpus Gertsch & Davis, 1940 (Araneae: Phrurolithidae) from Mexico

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: A new species of Phonotimpus Gertsch & Davis, 1940 (Araneae: Phrurolithidae) from Mexico

subSubSection.paragraph:
Type material.
Holotype ♂ : MEXICO :
Estado de Mexico
: Municipio de Temazcaltepec , San Francisco Oxtotilpan ,
13 February 1984
, pine-oak forest, M.L. Jiménez leg. ( CARCIB 0218 )
.
Allotype : ♀ , same data as holotype except 14

Etymology. The specific epithet is a patronym in honor of Dr María Luisa Jiménez (CIBNOR, Mexico ), who has improved the knowledge of Mexican spiders and who collected the type series of this species.

Diagnosis. Among congeners, females of
P. marialuisae
sp. nov.
share only with
P. separatus
the single atrium with the copulatory opening located in the middle of the epigynal plate ( Figs 1G, J ) and the spermathecae positioned posterior to the copulatory opening. It can be separated from the latter species by the short copulatory ducts with the first part widened, sclerotized and touching one another just after the copulatory opening, forming a copulatory duct chamber (CDC in Figs 1H, I, K ), and by the oblong bursae arising from the sides of the CDC ( Figs 1H, I, K ). Males of
P. marialuisae
sp. nov.
differ from
P. pennimani
and
P. talquian
by having a conspicuous palpal femoral groove associated with the femoral apophysis (RFG and FA in Figs 2E, F ), a rhomboid-shaped conductor, embolus pointing to the ectal side ( Figs 2 A–B), and a distal spur-like tegular apophysis (TS in Figs 2H, I ).

caption.paragraph:
FIGURE 1.
Phonotimpus marialuisae
sp. nov.
A–B. Female, dorsal view; C–D. Female, ventral view; E. Male, dorsal view; F. Male, ventral view, arrow points to ventral scutum; G–K. Epigynum, G. Ventral view; H–I, K. Dorsal view; J. Ventro-lateral view; L. Preening brush on metatarsus III; M. Female tarsal organ, leg I; N. Same, leg II. Scale A–F: 0.5 mm; G–K: 0.2 mm; L: 0.05 mm; M– N: 0.005 mm. Abbreviations: A, atrium; B, bursa; CDC, copulatory duct chamber; CO, copulatory opening; FD, fertilization duct; S, spermatheca.

FIGURE 2. Male palpus of
Phonotimpus marialuisae
sp. nov.
A. Ventral view; B. Detail of the copulatory bulb, arrow points to lobe of embolar basal process and asterisk is over base of embolus; C. Cymbium and tibia, dorsal view; arrow on cymbial groove; D. Retrolateral view; E. Femur, retrolateral view; F. Femur, ventral view; G. Tibia, retrolateral view; H. Dissected copulatory bulb, dorsal view; I. Detail of the copulatory bulb, dorsal view. Scale A–H: 0.1 mm; I: 0.05 mm. Abbreviations: C, conductor; Cb, cymbium; DTA, dorsal tibial apophysis; E, embolus; EBP, embolar basal process; FA, femoral apophysis; PFS, prolateral femoral setae; RFG, retrolateral femoral groove; RTA, retrolateral tibial apophysis; T, tegulum; TS, tegular spur.

subSubSection.paragraph:
Variation. Males (n=5) total length 1.72–1.94; carapace 0.84–0.91 long, 0.68–0.77 wide. Male scutum ranges from occupying roughly 1/2 to 2/3 of opisthosoma length. Females (n=8) total length 2.32–2.67; carapace 0.89–1.05 long, 0.75–0.88 wide. The female scutum ranges from occupying roughly 1/4 to 1/3. Some males and females have only four white cream chevrons on dorsum of opisthosoma. All specimens have one dorsal spine on femora II–IV, but four females (including the allotype ) have one smaller dorsal spine on femora I. As in
P. pennimani
or
P. talquian ,
some specimens have one more or one less spine on tibiae I or II, but the leg in the opposite side has the number of macrosetae noted in the holotype .
Distribution. MEXICO , only known from the type locality.

Taxonomic comments. Females of
P. pennimani
and
P. talquian
do not have a copulatory duct chamber as described here, but
P. separatus
(see
Chamé-Vázquez et al. 2018
, figs 1E–G) and some
Otacilia
species (see
Wang et al. 2015
, figs 2F–G, 4F–G) have the copulatory ducts widened just after the copulatory opening. However, none of those species have the widened part of the copulatory ducts as contiguous, as in
P. marialuisae
sp. nov.
The conformation of the male palp of
P. marialuisae
sp. nov.
is different from
P. pennimani
or
P. talquian
. In those, the palpal retrolateral femoral groove, femoral apophysis and the dorsal groove on cymbium are inconspicuous, the RTA is tapering, the conductor is tube-like, embolus points distally and the tegular spur is absent (
Chamé-Vázquez et al. 2018
). There are still several undescribed species of phrurolithids from Mexico and Central America, most of them can be assigned to
Phonotimpus
(Platnick pers. comm.). However, this genus is not completely circumscribed because the male of the genotype is unknown.
